<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=0>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="66%"><FONT SIZE=2>Net expense for employee benefit plans</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>635</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>347</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>330</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The 2004 net expense for employee benefit plans of $635&nbsp;million increased by $288&nbsp;million over the 2003 amount. This cost increase primarily relates
to increased postemployment benefit costs, resulting from several workforce reduction programs during 2004 as part of the overall restructuring program ($167&nbsp;million), and a lowering of the
Company's discount rate assumption on its pension and postretirement benefit plans, partially offset by the impact of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003
discussed below. The 2003 net expense for employee benefit plans of $347&nbsp;million increased by $17&nbsp;million over the 2002 amount. This cost increase primarily relates to higher settlement
losses in the U.S. pension plan, a lowering of the Company's discount rate assumption on its pension and postretirement benefit plans, increased amortization of deferred losses, as well as higher
matching of employee contributions in the savings plan, partially offset by $148&nbsp;million of costs in 2002 associated with voluntary early retirement and integration programs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2003, the United States enacted into law the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 (the "Act"). The Act establishes a prescription drug
benefit under Medicare, known as "Medicare Part&nbsp;D," and a federal subsidy to sponsors of retiree health care benefit plans that provide a benefit that is at least actuarially equivalent to
Medicare Part&nbsp;D. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
May&nbsp;2004, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued FASB Staff Position No.&nbsp;106-2, "Accounting and Disclosure Requirements Related to the
Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003" ("FSP 106-2"). FSP 106-2 requires companies to account for the effect of the subsidy on benefits
attributable to past service as an actuarial experience gain and as a reduction of the service cost component of net postretirement health care costs for amounts attributable to current service, if
the benefit provided is at least actuarially equivalent to Medicare Part&nbsp;D. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company adopted FSP 106-2 in the third quarter of 2004. The impact of adoption for 2004 was a reduction of pre-tax net postretirement health care costs and an
increase in net earnings of $24&nbsp;million. In addition, as of July&nbsp;1, 2004, the Company reduced its accumulated postretirement benefit obligation for the subsidy related to benefits
attributed to past service by $315&nbsp;million and decreased its unrecognized actuarial losses by the same amount. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2004, for the U.S. pension and postretirement plans, the Company reduced its discount rate assumption from 6.25% to 5.75% and modified its health care cost trend
rate assumption. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company reduced its long-term rate of return assumption from 9.0% to 8.0% based on the investment return of its pension assets, which are
primarily in U.S. equity securities. The Company presently anticipates that these assumption changes, coupled with the amortization of lower returns on pension fund assets in prior years, partially
offset by the full year effect of adopting Medicare Part&nbsp;D, will result in an increase in 2005 pre-tax benefit expense of approximately $200&nbsp;million, or approximately $0.08
per share. The expected increase in benefit expense is prior to the consideration of any impact of the three-year restructuring program announced in January&nbsp;2004. While the Company
does not presently anticipate a change in its 2005 assumptions, a fifty-basis point decline (increase) in the Company's discount rate would increase (decrease) the Company's pension and postretirement </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>19</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=20,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=490962,FOLIO='19',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DI1150A.;8',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='10-MAR-2005;14:05' -->
<A NAME="page_di1150_1_20"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>expense
by approximately $65&nbsp;million. Similarly, a fifty-basis point decrease (increase) in the expected return on plan assets would increase (decrease) the Company's pension expense for the
U.S. pension plans by approximately $31&nbsp;million. See Note&nbsp;15 to the consolidated financial statements for a sensitivity discussion of the assumed health care cost trend rates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue Recognition.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As required by U.S. GAAP, the Company recognizes revenues, net of sales incentives, and including
shipping and handling charges billed to customers, upon shipment of goods when title and risk of loss pass to customers. Shipping and handling costs are classified as part of cost of sales. Provisions
and allowances for estimated sales returns and bad debts are also recorded in the Company's consolidated financial statements. The amounts recorded for these provisions and related allowances are not
significant to the Company's consolidated financial position or results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation, Amortization and Goodwill Valuation.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company depreciates property, plant and equipment and amortizes
definite life intangibles using straight-line methods over the estimated useful lives of the assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company is required to conduct an annual review of goodwill and intangible assets for potential impairment. Goodwill impairment testing requires a comparison between the carrying
value and fair value of each reporting unit. If the carrying value exceeds the fair value, goodwill is considered impaired. The amount of impairment loss is measured as the difference between the
carrying value and implied fair value of goodwill, which is determined using discounted cash flows. Impairment testing for non-amortizable intangible assets requires a comparison between
fair value and carrying value of the intangible asset. If the carrying value exceeds fair value, the intangible asset is considered impaired and is reduced to fair value. These calculations may be
affected by the market conditions noted below in the Business Environment section, as well as interest rates and general economic conditions. During 2004, the Company completed its annual review of
goodwill and intangible assets. This review resulted in a $29&nbsp;million non-cash pre-tax charge related to intangible asset impairments for a small confectionery business
in the United States and certain brands in Mexico. A portion of this
charge, $12&nbsp;million, was recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of earnings. The remainder of the charge, $17&nbsp;million, is included in discontinued
operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Impairment of Long-Lived Assets.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company reviews long-lived assets, including amortizable
intangible assets, for impairment whenever events or changes in business circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may not be fully recoverable. The Company performs undiscounted
operating cash flow analyses to determine if an impairment exists. For purposes of recognition and measurement of an impairment for assets held for use, the Company groups assets and liabilities at
the lowest level for which cash flows are separately identifiable. If an impairment is determined to exist, any related impairment loss is calculated based on fair value. Impairment losses on assets
to be disposed of, if any, are based on the estimated proceeds to be received, less costs of disposal. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Marketing and Advertising Costs.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As required by U.S. GAAP, the Company records marketing costs as an expense in the year to
which such costs relate. The Company does not defer amounts on its year-end consolidated balance sheet with respect to marketing costs. The Company expenses advertising costs as incurred.
Consumer incentive and trade promotion activities are recorded as a reduction of revenues based on amounts estimated as being due to customers and consumers at the end of a period, based principally
on historical utilization and redemption rates. For interim reporting purposes, advertising and consumer incentive expenses are charged to operations as a percentage of volume, based on estimated
volume and related expense for the full year. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related Party Transactions.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note&nbsp;4 to the consolidated financial statements, Altria
Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s subsidiary, Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., provides the Company with various services, including planning, legal, treasury, accounting, auditing, insurance, human
resources, office of the secretary, corporate affairs, information technology, aviation and tax services. Billings for these services, </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>20</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=21,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=85990,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DI1150A.;8',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='10-MAR-2005;14:05' -->
<A NAME="page_di1150_1_21"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>which
were based on the cost to Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. to provide such services and a management fee, were $310&nbsp;million, $318&nbsp;million and $327&nbsp;million for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively. These costs were paid to Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. monthly. Although the cost of these services cannot be quantified on
a stand-alone basis, management has assessed that the billings are reasonable based on the level of support provided by Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., and that they reflect all services
provided. The cost and nature of the services are reviewed annually by the Company's Audit Committee, which is comprised of independent directors. The effects of these transactions are included in
operating cash flows in the Company's consolidated statements of cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2004, the Company purchased two corporate aircraft from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $47&nbsp;million. The
Company also entered into an Aircraft Management Agreement with Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. in
December&nbsp;2004, pursuant to which Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. agreed to perform aircraft management, pilot services, maintenance and other aviation services for the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. provided to the Company certain financial services, including payroll and accounts payable processing, at a cost of approximately
$25&nbsp;million, which was included in the $310&nbsp;million charge shown above. Beginning in 2005, the Company will perform these functions for itself at a similar cost. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the Company had short-term amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. of $227&nbsp;million and $543&nbsp;million, respectively.
Interest on these borrowings is based on the applicable London Interbank Offered Rate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Taxes.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company accounts for income taxes in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS")
No.&nbsp;109, "Accounting for Income Taxes." The accounts of the Company are included in the consolidated federal income tax return of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. Income taxes are generally computed
on a separate company basis. To the extent that foreign tax credits, capital losses and other credits generated by the Company, which cannot currently be utilized on a separate company basis, are
utilized in Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax return, the benefit is recognized in the calculation of the Company's provision for income taxes. Based on the Company's current
estimate, this benefit is calculated to be approximately $70&nbsp;million, $100&nbsp;million and $240&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively. The
benefit is dependent on a variety of tax attributes that have a tendency to vary year to year. The Company makes payments to, or is reimbursed by, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. for the tax effects
resulting from its inclusion in Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax return. The provision for income taxes is based on domestic and international statutory income tax rates and
tax planning opportunities available to the Company in the jurisdictions in which it operates. Significant judgment is required in determining income tax provisions and in evaluating tax positions.
The Company establishes additional provisions for income taxes when, despite the belief that existing tax positions are fully supportable, there remain certain positions that are likely to be
challenged and that may not be sustained on review by tax authorities. The Company adjusts these additional accruals in light of changing facts and circumstances. The consolidated tax provision
includes the impact of changes to accruals that are considered appropriate, as well as the related net interest. If the Company's filing positions are ultimately upheld under audits by respective
taxing authorities, it is possible that the provision for income taxes in future years may reflect favorable adjustments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
October&nbsp;22, 2004, the American Jobs Creation Act ("the Jobs Act") was signed into law. The Jobs Act provides for a deduction of 85% of certain foreign earnings that are
repatriated. The Company may elect to apply this provision to qualifying earnings repatriations in 2005 and is conducting analyses of its effects. The U.S. Treasury Department recently provided
additional clarifying language on key elements of the provision, which is under consideration as part of the Company's evaluation. The </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>21</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=22,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=293811,FOLIO='21',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DI1150A.;8',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='10-MAR-2005;14:05' -->
<A NAME="page_di1150_1_22"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Company
expects to complete its evaluation of the effects of the repatriation provision within a reasonable period of time. The Company does not expect the repatriation provisions of the Jobs Act to
have a significant impact on its consolidated results of operations or its consolidated cash flows. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Jobs Act also provides tax relief to U.S. domestic manufacturers by providing a tax deduction of up to 9% of the lesser of "qualified production activities income" or taxable income.
In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position 109-1, "Application of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;109, 'Accounting for Income Taxes,' to the Tax Deduction on Qualified
Production Activities Provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004" ("FSP 109-1"). FSP 109-1 requires companies to account for this deduction as a "special deduction"
rather than a rate reduction, in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;109, and therefore, the Company will recognize these benefits, which are not expected to be significant, in the year earned. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidation.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., as well as its wholly-owned and
majority-owned subsidiaries. Investments in which Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. exercises significant influence (20%&#151;50% ownership interest), are accounted for under the equity method of
accounting. Investments in which Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. has an ownership interest of less than 20%, or does not exercise significant influence, are accounted for with the cost method of accounting.
All intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Business Environment  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is subject to a number of challenges that may adversely affect its businesses. These challenges, which are discussed below and under the
"Forward-Looking and Cautionary Statements" section in Part&nbsp;I, Item&nbsp;1 of this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K, include: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>fluctuations
in commodity prices;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>movements
of foreign currencies;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>competitive
challenges in various products and markets, including price gaps with competitor products and the increasing price-consciousness of consumers;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
rising cost environment;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
trend toward increasing consolidation in the retail trade and consequent pricing pressure and inventory reductions;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
growing presence of hard discount retailers, primarily in Europe, with an emphasis on own-label products;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>changing
consumer preferences, including diet trends;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>competitors
with different profit objectives and less susceptibility to currency exchange rates; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>concerns
and/or regulations regarding food safety, quality and health, including genetically modified organisms, trans-fatty acids and obesity. Increased government
regulation of the food industry could result in increased costs to the Company. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fluctuations
in commodity prices can lead to retail price volatility and intense price competition, and can influence consumer and trade buying patterns. During 2004, the Company's
commodity costs on average have been higher than those incurred in 2003 (most notably dairy, coffee, meat, nuts, energy and packaging), and have adversely affected earnings. Dairy costs rose to
historical highs during the first half of 2004, but have moderated during the second half of 2004. For 2004, the Company had a negative pre-tax impact from all commodities of approximately
$930&nbsp;million as compared with 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the ordinary course of business, the Company is subject to many influences that can impact the timing of sales to customers, including the timing of holidays and other annual or
special events, seasonality of certain products, significant weather conditions, timing of Company and customer </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=23,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=339465,FOLIO='22',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DI1150A.;8',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='10-MAR-2005;14:05' -->
<A NAME="page_di1150_1_23"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>incentive
programs, customer inventory programs, Company initiatives to improve supply chain efficiency, including efforts to align product shipments more closely with consumption by shifting some of
its customer marketing programs to a consumption based approach, financial situations of customers and general economic conditions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To
build its business while confronting these challenges, the Company operates with seven business strategies: 1)&nbsp;build superior consumer brand value; 2)&nbsp;build shopper
demand through superior customer collaboration; 3)&nbsp;transform the portfolio; 4)&nbsp;expand global scale; 5)&nbsp;drive out costs and assets; 6)&nbsp;strengthen employee and organizational
excellence; and 7)&nbsp;act responsibly. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
first strategy&#151;to build superior consumer brand value&#151;involves improving the Company's products, using more value-added packaging, developing innovative new
products and managing price gaps effectively. During 2004, the Company increased marketing spending by approximately $460&nbsp;million versus 2003 to manage price gaps, to increase media presence,
to drive growth, to enhance brand equity and to support new products. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
second strategy&#151;to build shopper demand through superior customer collaboration&#151;recognizes the importance of the Company's retail partners in fulfilling its
vision. The Company works together with its customers to better understand consumer behavior in their stores, to develop in-store programs that increase shopper demand, and to reduce costs
through more efficient store delivery systems. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
third strategy is to transform the portfolio. Through innovation, investment, acquisition and divestiture, the Company is accelerating the shift in its portfolio toward
businesses&#151;whether global, regional or local&#151;that offer the Company a sustainable competitive advantage, and will better enable its management to focus on opportunities that
meet consumer needs and create long-term value for the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
particular, the Company is responding to growing consumer demand for products that meet health and wellness and convenience needs. The Company is enhancing the nutrition profile of
its portfolio by creating new products and by reformulating existing products, including reducing or eliminating trans-fat wherever possible. The Company is addressing convenience needs by
offering more convenient packaging, such as single-serve and resealable packaging, and products requiring reduced preparation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fourth strategy&#151;to expand the Company's global scale&#151;focuses on improving its growth prospects in key developing markets that offer the greatest growth
potential. In particular, the Company is expanding its marketing and infrastructure investments in large, growing markets, such as China, Brazil, Mexico and Russia. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fifth strategy&#151;to drive out costs and assets&#151;includes the Company's announced three-year restructuring program, with the objectives of realigning
and lowering its cost structure and optimizing capacity utilization. As part of this program (which is discussed further in Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated financial statements), the Company
anticipates the closing or sale of up to twenty plants and the elimination of approximately six thousand positions. From 2004 through 2006, the Company expects to incur up to $1.2&nbsp;billion in
pre-tax charges, reflecting asset disposals, severance and other implementation costs, including $641&nbsp;million incurred in 2004. Approximately one-half of the
pre-tax charges are expected to require cash payments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, the Company expects to incur approximately $140&nbsp;million in capital expenditures from 2004 through 2006 to implement the restructuring program, including
$46&nbsp;million spent in 2004. Cost savings as a result of the restructuring program were approximately $127&nbsp;million in 2004, are expected to increase by an incremental amount between
$120&nbsp;million and $140&nbsp;million in 2005, and are anticipated to reach annualized cost savings of approximately $400&nbsp;million by 2006, all of which are expected to be used in
supporting brand-building initiatives. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=24,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=332465,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DI1150A.;8',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='10-MAR-2005;14:05' -->
<A NAME="page_di1150_1_24"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
sixth strategy&#151;to strengthen employee and organizational excellence&#151;reflects the need to develop organizational capabilities and support employees in meeting
the Company's business challenges, wherever they work. In this regard, during 2004 the Company completed a reorganization and resource alignment for a new global structure. In addition, a new vision
for the organization&#151;to help people around the world eat and live better&#151;was introduced, while human resource policies, processes and practices were harmonized across the
Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
final strategy is to act responsibly. As the Company strives for sustainable growth, it seeks business success in ways that honor ethical and legal standards and that respect people,
communities and the natural environment. This strategy includes a commitment to strong compliance and integrity programs and sound corporate governance, as well as a number of health and wellness
initiatives, such as enhanced nutrition labeling, the development and funding of community-based programs and voluntary limitations on advertising to younger children. It also includes taking steps to
contribute to the sustainability of the Company's agricultural supply base through several programs with respected international and local partners. The Company outlines its
commitment to corporate responsibility in the Kraft Code of Conduct for employees and at www.kraft.com/responsibility/home.aspx. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions and Dispositions:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;One element of the third strategy is to strengthen the Company's brand portfolios through disciplined programs of selective acquisitions and divestitures. The
Company is constantly reviewing potential acquisition candidates and from time to time sells businesses to accelerate the shift in its portfolio toward businesses&#151;whether global, regional
or local&#151;that offer the Company a sustainable competitive advantage. The impact of any future acquisition or divestiture could have a material impact on the Company's consolidated
financial position, results of operations or cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
November&nbsp;15, 2004, the Company announced the sale of substantially all of its sugar confectionery business for approximately $1.5&nbsp;billion. The proposed sale includes the </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Life Savers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>,
</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Creme Savers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Altoids</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Trolli</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> and </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Sugus</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> brands. The
transaction, which is subject to regulatory approval, is expected to be
completed in the second quarter of 2005. The Company has reflected the results of its sugar confectionery business as discontinued operations on the consolidated statements of earnings for all years
presented. The assets related to the sugar confectionery business were reflected as assets of discontinued operations held for sale on the consolidated balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2004. In
addition, the Company anticipates additional tax expense of approximately $270&nbsp;million to be recorded as a loss on sale of discontinued operations in 2005. In accordance with the provisions of
SFAS No.&nbsp;109, the tax expense will be recorded when the transaction is consummated. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, the Company acquired a U.S.-based beverage business for a total cost of $137&nbsp;million. During 2003, the Company acquired a biscuits business in Egypt and trademarks
associated with a small U.S.-based natural foods business. The total cost of these and other smaller acquisitions was $98&nbsp;million. During 2002, the Company acquired a snacks business in Turkey
and a biscuits business in Australia. The total cost of these and other smaller acquisitions was $122&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, the Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and trademarks associated with a candy business in Norway. The aggregate proceeds received from the sale of these businesses
were $18&nbsp;million, on which pre-tax losses of $3&nbsp;million were recorded. In December&nbsp;2004, the Company announced the sale of its U.K. desserts business for approximately
$135&nbsp;million, which is expected to result in an estimated gain of $0.04 per share. The transaction closed in the first quarter of 2005. The Company also announced in December&nbsp;2004, the
sale of its yogurt business for approximately $59&nbsp;million, which is expected to result in an after-tax loss of approximately $12&nbsp;million ($5&nbsp;million in 2004, with the
remainder at closing). The transaction, which is also subject to regulatory approval, is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2005. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=25,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=208204,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DI1150A.;8',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='10-MAR-2005;14:05' -->
<A NAME="page_di1150_1_25"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2003, the Company sold a European rice business and a branded fresh cheese business in Italy. The aggregate proceeds received from sales of businesses were $96&nbsp;million, on
which the Company recorded pre-tax gains of $31&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2002, the Company sold several small North American food businesses, some of which had been previously classified as businesses held for sale arising from the acquisition of
Nabisco. In addition, the Company sold its Latin American yeast and industrial bakery ingredients business for approximately $110&nbsp;million and recorded a pre-tax gain of
$69&nbsp;million. The aggregate proceeds received from sales of businesses were $219&nbsp;million, on which the Company recorded pre-tax gains of $80&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
operating results of the businesses acquired and sold, excluding the sugar confectionery business, were not material to the Company's consolidated financial position, results of
operations or cash flows in any of the periods presented. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating income was affected by the following items during 2004, 2003 and 2002: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset impairment, exit and implementation costs</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;As discussed in Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated financial
statements, during 2004, the Company recorded $603&nbsp;million of asset impairment and exit costs on its consolidated statement of earnings. The Company also recorded $50&nbsp;million of
pre-tax implementation costs and $47&nbsp;million of pre-tax impairment charges relating to its equity investment in a joint venture in Turkey. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2003, the Company recorded a pre-tax charge of $6&nbsp;million for asset impairment and exit costs related to the closure of a Nordic snacks
plant. During 2002, the Company recorded a pre-tax charge of $142&nbsp;million related to employee acceptances under a voluntary retirement program. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Losses (Gains) on Sales of Businesses</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;During 2004, the Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and
trademarks associated with a candy business in Norway for aggregate pre-tax losses of $3&nbsp;million. During 2003, the Company sold a European rice business and a branded fresh cheese
business in Italy for aggregate pre-tax gains of $31&nbsp;million. During 2002, the Company sold its Latin American yeast and industrial bakery ingredients business, resulting in a
pre-tax gain of $69&nbsp;million, and several small food businesses, resulting in pre-tax gains of $11&nbsp;million. These pre-tax losses (gains) were included
in the operating companies income of the following segments: </FONT></DD></DL>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=29,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=380877,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DK1150A.;11',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:21' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1150_1_29"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note&nbsp;14 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company's management uses operating companies income, which is defined as operating
income before general corporate expenses and amortization of intangibles, to evaluate segment performance and allocate resources. Management believes it is appropriate to disclose this measure to help
investors analyze the business performance and trends of the various business segments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2004 compared with 2003  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares consolidated operating results for 2004 with 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
increased 509&nbsp;million pounds (2.8%), due primarily to acquisitions and increased shipments in the U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America Foodservice segment, partially
offset by the impact of divested businesses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $1,670&nbsp;million (5.5%), due primarily to favorable currency ($838&nbsp;million), higher volume/mix ($560&nbsp;million), higher net pricing
($265&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing, partially offset by increased promotional spending) and the impact of acquisitions ($140&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of
divested businesses ($126&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
income decreased $1,248&nbsp;million (21.3%), due primarily to the pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($597&nbsp;million), unfavorable costs,
net of higher pricing ($442&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($306&nbsp;million), the
2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($50&nbsp;million), the 2004 equity investment impairment charge relating to a joint venture in Turkey ($47&nbsp;million), the
unfavorable net impact related to gains and losses on the sales of businesses ($34&nbsp;million), higher fixed manufacturing costs ($23&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs) and the impact
of divestitures ($18&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher volume/mix ($187&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($98&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Currency
movements increased net revenues by $838&nbsp;million and operating income by $98&nbsp;million. These increases were due primarily to the weakness of the U.S. dollar against
the euro and the Canadian dollar. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's reported effective income tax rate decreased by 2.6&nbsp;percentage points to 32.3%, resulting from an $81&nbsp;million favorable resolution of an outstanding tax item,
the majority of which occurred in the third quarter of 2004, and the reversal of $35&nbsp;million of tax accruals that are no longer required due to tax events that occurred during the first quarter
of 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings
from continuing operations of $2,669&nbsp;million decreased $710&nbsp;million (21.0%), due primarily to lower operating income, partially offset by a lower effective income
tax rate. Diluted EPS from continuing operations, which was $1.55, decreased by 20.5%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings
from discontinued operations, net of income tax, decreased $101&nbsp;million, resulting in a net loss of $4&nbsp;million in 2004. The decrease was due primarily to
pre-tax non-cash asset impairment charges in 2004 of $107&nbsp;million ($69&nbsp;million after-tax) and an intangible pre-tax asset impairment
charge of $17&nbsp;million ($11&nbsp;million after-tax). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
earnings of $2,665&nbsp;million decreased $811&nbsp;million (23.3%). Diluted EPS from net earnings, which was $1.55, decreased by 22.9%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2003 compared with 2002  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares consolidated operating results for 2003 with 2002. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
increased 139&nbsp;million pounds (0.8%), due primarily to increased shipments in the U.S.&nbsp;Beverages segment and the U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America
Foodservice segment, growth </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=30,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=44050,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DK1150A.;11',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:21' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1150_1_30"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>in
developing markets and the impact of acquisitions, partially offset by the impact of divested businesses, lower consumption in certain categories, particularly U.S. cookies, trade inventory
reductions, price competition and the impact of a weaker global economy. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $1,250&nbsp;million (4.3%), due to favorable currency ($726&nbsp;million), higher pricing ($477&nbsp;million, reflecting higher commodity and currency
devaluation-driven cost increases, partially offset by higher promotional spending), higher volume/mix ($75&nbsp;million) and the impact of acquisitions ($59&nbsp;million), partially offset by the
impact of divested businesses ($87&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
income decreased $101&nbsp;million (1.7%), due primarily to higher fixed manufacturing costs ($113&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs), higher marketing,
administration and research costs ($106&nbsp;million), unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($77&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending),
unfavorable volume/mix ($74&nbsp;million), the impact of gains on sales of businesses ($49&nbsp;million) and the impact of divestitures ($18&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of
lower pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($136&nbsp;million) and the impact from integration costs and a loss on sale of a food factory ($124&nbsp;million) and
favorable currency ($93&nbsp;million). The higher benefit costs were primarily related to pension and stock compensation costs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Currency
movements increased net revenues by $726&nbsp;million and operating income by $93&nbsp;million. These increases were due primarily to the weakening of the U.S. dollar
against the euro, the Canadian dollar and other currencies, partially offset by the strength of the U.S. dollar against certain Latin American currencies. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
and other debt expense, net, decreased $182&nbsp;million. This decrease is due to the Company's refinancing of notes payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and the use of free
cash flow to pay down debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's reported effective income tax rate decreased by 0.6&nbsp;percentage points to 34.9%, due primarily to rate differences from foreign operations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings
from continuing operations of $3,379&nbsp;million increased $82&nbsp;million (2.5%), due primarily to lower interest expense and a lower effective income tax rate, partially
offset by lower operating income. Diluted EPS from continuing operations, which was $1.95, increased by 2.6%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
earnings of $3,476&nbsp;million increased $82&nbsp;million (2.4%). Diluted EPS from net earnings, which was $2.01, increased by 2.6%. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=31,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=657112,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DK1150A.;11',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:21' -->

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2004 compared with 2003  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares Kraft North America Commercial's operating results for 2004 with 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
increased 4.3%, due primarily to an acquisition in the U.S. Beverages segment and increased shipments in the U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America Foodservice segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $1,123&nbsp;million (5.4%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($537&nbsp;million), higher net pricing ($312&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven price
increases, partially offset by
increased promotional spending), favorable currency ($164&nbsp;million) and the impact of acquisitions ($117&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $788&nbsp;million (16.9%), due primarily to the 2004 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($391&nbsp;million),
unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($356&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), higher marketing, administration and research costs
($214&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($40&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher volume/mix
($197&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($29&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=32,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=845402,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DK1150A.;11',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:21' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1150_1_32"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following discusses operating results within each of Kraft North America Commercial's reportable segments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Beverages.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 12.7%, due primarily to the 2004 acquisition of a beverage business
and new product introductions in refreshment beverages. In coffee, volume also increased, due to product quality improvements and the impact of an expanded distribution arrangement. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $122&nbsp;million (5.0%), due primarily to the impact of acquisitions ($94&nbsp;million) and higher volume/mix ($85&nbsp;million), partially offset by
increased promotional spending ($56&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $151&nbsp;million (24.0%), due primarily to higher marketing, administration and research costs ($98&nbsp;million), unfavorable costs and higher
promotional spending ($85&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs), the 2004 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($9&nbsp;million) and the 2004 implementation
costs associated with the restructuring program ($4&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher volume/mix ($49&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America Foodservice.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 3.5%, due primarily to
higher volume in foodservice and cheese. Volume in the foodservice business increased, due primarily to an acquisition of a beverage business in 2004 and higher shipments to national accounts. Cheese
volume also increased, benefiting from increased promotional spending. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $704&nbsp;million (10.5%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($272&nbsp;million), higher pricing, net of higher promotional reinvestment spending in cheese
($248&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing), favorable currency ($164&nbsp;million) and the impact of acquisitions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $282&nbsp;million (22.2%), due primarily to unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($214&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs and
increased promotional spending), the 2004 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($111&nbsp;million), higher fixed manufacturing costs ($50&nbsp;million, including higher
benefit costs), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($26&nbsp;million) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($8&nbsp;million), partially
offset by higher volume/mix ($99&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($29&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Convenient Meals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 1.6%, due primarily to gains in meats and pizza, partially
offset by lower shipments in meals. Meats volume increased driven by higher consumption of cold cuts, supported by higher investment spending. Pizza volume also increased, aided by new product
introductions. In meals, volume declined due to the discontinuation of certain product lines in the second half of 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $192&nbsp;million (4.7%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($114&nbsp;million), higher pricing ($75&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in
meats and pizza) and the impact of acquisitions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $46&nbsp;million (5.6%), due primarily to the 2004 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($41&nbsp;million), higher
marketing, administration and research costs ($38&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs), the impact of acquisitions ($5&nbsp;million) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with the
restructuring program ($4&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher volume/mix ($40&nbsp;million) and higher pricing, net of unfavorable costs ($7&nbsp;million, including higher commodity
costs). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Grocery.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 0.7%, due primarily to gains in enhancers, partially offset by a
decline in desserts. Volume increased in enhancers, due primarily to mayonnaise and salad dressings. In desserts, volume declined, due primarily to lower shipments of fruit snacks, partially offset by
higher shipments in frozen toppings. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=33,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=587270,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DK1150A.;11',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:21' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1150_1_33"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $37&nbsp;million (1.5%), due primarily to higher pricing and lower promotional spending ($34&nbsp;million) and higher volume/mix. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income was equal to the prior year, as lower fixed manufacturing costs ($17&nbsp;million) and higher volume/mix ($10&nbsp;million) were offset by the 2004
pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($8&nbsp;million), the 2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($6&nbsp;million), higher marketing,
administration and research costs ($5&nbsp;million) and unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Snacks&nbsp;&amp; Cereals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 1.5%, as higher salted snacks and biscuits volume was
partially offset by a decline in cereals. Salted snacks volume increased due to consumer nutrition trends and marketing programs in nuts. In biscuits, volume increased, driven by new product
introductions. In cereals, volume declined due to low carbohydrate diet trends, which impacted the category, and increased competitive activity. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $68&nbsp;million (1.3%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($62&nbsp;million) and higher pricing ($11&nbsp;million, including the absence of high product
returns associated with new products incurred in the prior year, partially offset by increased promotional spending). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $309&nbsp;million (29.5%), due primarily to the 2004 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($222&nbsp;million),
unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($62&nbsp;million, due to higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), higher marketing, administration and research costs
($47&nbsp;million) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($18&nbsp;million), partially offset by lower fixed manufacturing costs ($40&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2003 compared with 2002  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares Kraft North America Commercial's operating results for 2003 with 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
increased 1.5%, due primarily to contributions from new products and increased shipments in the U.S. Beverages segment and the U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America
Foodservice segment, partially offset by the divestiture of a small confectionery business in 2002, consumption weakness in certain categories, primarily cookies, and trade inventory reductions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $448&nbsp;million (2.2%), due primarily to favorable currency ($162&nbsp;million), higher pricing, net of increased promotional spending ($157&nbsp;million)
and higher volume/mix ($148&nbsp;million), partially offset by the divestiture of a small confectionery business in 2002 ($21&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $6&nbsp;million (0.1%), due primarily to unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($132&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs and
increased promotional spending), higher fixed manufacturing costs ($82&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs) and unfavorable volume/mix ($35&nbsp;million), partially offset by 2002
pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($135&nbsp;million) and the impact of lower integration costs and a loss on sale of a food factory ($107&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following discusses operating results within each of Kraft North America Commercial's reportable segments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Beverages.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 7.8%, due primarily to higher shipments of
ready-to-drink beverages, which were aided by new product introductions. In coffee, volume declined, impacted by competitive activity and a category decline due to higher
prices. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $95&nbsp;million (4.1%), due to higher volume/mix ($82&nbsp;million) and lower promotional spending, net of lower pricing ($13&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $54&nbsp;million (9.4%), due primarily to the impact of lower integration costs ($58&nbsp;million), higher volume/mix ($33&nbsp;million) and
the 2002 pre-tax charges for asset </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=34,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=941085,FOLIO='33',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DK1150A.;11',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:21' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1150_1_34"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>impairment
and exit costs ($27&nbsp;million), partially offset by unfavorable costs, net of lower promotional spending ($32&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs), higher marketing,
administration and research costs ($27&nbsp;million) and higher benefit costs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America Foodservice.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 2.3%, due primarily to
higher shipments in cheese, foodservice and Canada. Cheese volume increased due primarily to improved consumption and share trends resulting from the investment program that began in the third quarter
of 2003. Volume for the foodservice business in the United States also increased, due to higher shipments to national accounts. Volume in Canada increased, driven by new beverage product
introductions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $317&nbsp;million (5.0%), due to favorable currency ($162&nbsp;million), higher volume/mix ($119&nbsp;million) and higher pricing ($36&nbsp;million,
including the impact of increased promotional spending). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $16&nbsp;million (1.3%), due primarily to the 2002 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($43&nbsp;million), favorable
currency ($32&nbsp;million), higher volume/mix ($21&nbsp;million) and lower integration costs ($8&nbsp;million), partially offset by unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($49&nbsp;million,
including higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($20&nbsp;million) and higher fixed manufacturing costs ($18&nbsp;million,
including higher benefit costs). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Convenient Meals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 0.3%, due primarily to gains in cold cuts, hot dogs, bacon,
soy-based meat alternatives and frozen pizza, partially offset by a decline in meals, due primarily to the discontinuance of certain product lines. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $84&nbsp;million (2.1%), due primarily to higher pricing ($59&nbsp;million) and higher volume/mix ($23&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $34&nbsp;million (4.3%), due primarily to the impact of 2002 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($36&nbsp;million)
and integration costs ($29&nbsp;million), lower fixed manufacturing costs ($18&nbsp;million) and higher pricing, net of unfavorable costs ($7&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs),
partially offset by higher marketing, administration and research costs ($53&nbsp;million) and higher benefit costs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Grocery.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 0.6%, due primarily to the divestiture of a small confectionery
business in 2002 and a decline in enhancers, partially offset by higher shipments in desserts. In enhancers, volume declined due primarily to lower shipments of spoonable dressings, partially offset
by gains in pourable dressings, barbeque sauce and steak sauce. In desserts, volume increased due primarily to higher shipments of sugar-free items and increased merchandising programs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $32&nbsp;million (1.4%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($29&nbsp;million) and higher pricing ($24&nbsp;million, including the impact of increased
promotional spending), partially offset by the divestiture of a small confectionery business in 2002 ($21&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $13&nbsp;million (1.5%), due primarily to the 2002 asset impairment and exit costs ($20&nbsp;million), favorable volume/mix ($17&nbsp;million)
and the impact of lower integration costs ($10&nbsp;million), partially offset by unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($20&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs), the gain on sale of
a small confectionery business in 2002 ($8&nbsp;million) and higher benefit costs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Snacks&nbsp;&amp; Cereals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 3.5%, due primarily to lower shipments in biscuits. In
biscuits, volume declined, due primarily to reduced consumption in cookies, reflecting higher pricing, lower impact of new products, and consumer health and wellness concerns. Snacks volume increased,
benefiting from category and consumption gains in snack nuts. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=35,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=735177,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DK1150A.;11',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:21' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1150_1_35"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues decreased $80&nbsp;million (1.5%), due to lower volume/mix ($105&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher pricing ($25&nbsp;million, including the impact of increased
promotional spending). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $123&nbsp;million (10.5%), due primarily to lower volume/mix ($102&nbsp;million), higher fixed manufacturing costs ($70&nbsp;million) and
unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($38&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), partially offset by lower marketing, administration and research
costs ($78&nbsp;million) and the impact of 2002 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($9&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Kraft International Commercial  </I></B></FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="7%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=0>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="62%"><FONT SIZE=2>Europe, Middle East&nbsp;&amp; Africa</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>683</FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1,393</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1,466</FONT></TD>

<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
