<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note 4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related Party Transactions:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s subsidiary, Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., provides the Company with various services, including planning, legal, treasury,
accounting, auditing, insurance, human resources, office of the secretary, corporate affairs, information technology, aviation and tax services. Billings for these services, which were based on the
cost to Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. to provide such services and a management fee, were $310&nbsp;million, $318&nbsp;million and $327&nbsp;million for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively. These costs were paid to Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. monthly. Although the cost of these services cannot be quantified on a
stand-alone basis, management has </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>59</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=60,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=972464,FOLIO='59',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DU1150A.;20',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_du1150_1_60"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>assessed
that the billings are reasonable based on the level of support provided by Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., and that they reflect all services provided. The cost and nature of the
services are reviewed annually by the Company's Audit Committee, which is comprised of independent directors. The effects of these transactions are included in operating cash flows in the Company's
consolidated statements of cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2004, the Company purchased two corporate aircraft from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $47&nbsp;million. The
Company also entered into an Aircraft Management Agreement with Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. in December&nbsp;2004, pursuant to which Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. agreed to
perform aircraft management, pilot services, maintenance and other aviation services for the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. provided to the Company certain financial services, including payroll and accounts payable processing, at a cost of approximately
$25&nbsp;million, which was included in the $310&nbsp;million charge shown above. Beginning in 2005, the Company will perform these functions for itself at a similar cost. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the Company had short-term amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. of $227&nbsp;million and $543&nbsp;million, respectively.
Interest on these borrowings is based on the applicable London Interbank Offered Rate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fair values of the Company's short-term amounts due to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and affiliates approximate carrying amounts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Divestitures:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Discontinued Operations:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On November&nbsp;15, 2004, the Company announced the sale of substantially all of its sugar confectionery business for approximately $1.5&nbsp;billion. The
proposed sale includes the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Life Savers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Creme Savers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Altoids</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Trolli</I></FONT><FONT
SIZE=2> and </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Sugus</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> brands. The transaction, which
is subject to regulatory approval, is expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2005. The Company has reflected the results of its sugar confectionery business as discontinued operations on
the consolidated statements of earnings for all years presented. Pursuant to the sugar confectionery sale agreement, the Company has agreed to provide certain transition and supply services to the
buyer. These service arrangements are primarily for terms of one year or less, with the exception of one supply arrangement with a term of not more than three years. The expected cash flow from this
supply arrangement is not significant. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summary
results of operations for the sugar confectionery business were as follows: </FONT></P>

provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;109, the tax expense will be recorded when the transaction is consummated. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Other:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2004, the Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and trademarks associated with a candy business in Norway. The aggregate proceeds received from the
sale of these businesses were $18&nbsp;million, on which pre-tax losses of $3&nbsp;million were recorded. In December&nbsp;2004, the Company announced the sale of its U.K. desserts
business for approximately $135&nbsp;million, which is expected to result in an estimated gain of $0.04 per share. The transaction, which is subject to required approvals, is expected to close in
the first quarter of 2005, following
completion of necessary employee consultation requirements. The Company also announced in December&nbsp;2004, the sale of its yogurt business for approximately $59&nbsp;million, which is expected
to result in an after-tax loss of approximately $12&nbsp;million ($5&nbsp;million in 2004, with the remainder at closing). The transaction, which is also subject to regulatory
approval, is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2003, the Company sold a European rice business and a branded fresh cheese business in Italy. The aggregate proceeds received from sales of businesses were $96&nbsp;million, on
which the Company recorded pre-tax gains of $31&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2002, the Company sold several small North American food businesses, some of which had been previously classified as businesses held for sale arising from the acquisition of
Nabisco. The net revenues and operating results of the businesses held for sale, which were not significant, were excluded from the Company's consolidated statements of earnings, and no gain or loss
was recognized on these sales. In addition, the Company sold its Latin American yeast and industrial bakery ingredients business for approximately $110&nbsp;million and recorded a
pre-tax gain of $69&nbsp;million. The aggregate proceeds received from sales of businesses were $219&nbsp;million, on which the Company recorded pre-tax gains of
$80&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
operating results of the other businesses sold, discussed above, were not material to the Company's consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows in any of the
periods presented. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Acquisitions:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2004, the Company acquired a U.S.-based beverage business for a total cost of $137&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2003, the Company acquired a biscuits business in Egypt and trademarks associated with a small U.S.-based natural foods business. The total cost of these and other smaller
acquisitions was $98&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2002, the Company acquired a snacks business in Turkey and a biscuits business in Australia. The total cost of these and other smaller acquisitions was $122&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>61</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_dw1150_1_62"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
effects of these acquisitions were not material to the Company's consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows in any of the periods presented. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Inventories:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The cost of approximately 37% and 39% of inventories in 2004 and 2003, respectively, was determined using the LIFO method. The stated LIFO amounts of inventories
were approximately $81&nbsp;million and $155&nbsp;million higher than the current cost of inventories at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Short-Term Borrowings and Borrowing Arrangements:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the Company had short-term borrowings of $1,818&nbsp;million and $2,453&nbsp;million, respectively,
consisting principally of commercial paper borrowings with an average year-end interest rate of 2.4% and 1.4%, respectively. Of these amounts, the Company reclassified
$1,900&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2003, of the commercial paper borrowings to long-term debt based upon its intent and ability to refinance these borrowings on a
long-term basis. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fair values of the Company's short-term borrowings at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, based upon current market interest rates, approximate the amounts disclosed
above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Following
a $10.1&nbsp;billion judgment on March&nbsp;21, 2003, against Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s domestic tobacco subsidiary, Philip Morris USA&nbsp;Inc., the three major credit
rating agencies took a series of ratings actions resulting in the lowering of the Company's short-term and long-term debt ratings, despite the fact the Company is neither a
party to, nor has exposure to, this litigation. The Company's credit ratings by Moody's at December&nbsp;31, 2004, were "P-2" for short-term debt and "A3" for
long-term-debt, with stable outlook. The Company's credit ratings by Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's at December&nbsp;31, 2004 were "A-2" for short-term debt
and "BBB+" for long-term debt, with stable outlook. The Company's credit ratings by Fitch Rating Services at December&nbsp;31, 2004 were "F-2" for short-term debt
and "BBB+" for long-term debt, with stable outlook. None of the Company's debt agreements requires accelerated repayment in the event of a decrease in credit ratings. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company maintains revolving credit facilities that have historically been used to support the issuance of commercial paper. The 364-day revolving credit facility expires
in July&nbsp;2005, although it contains a provision allowing the Company to extend the maturity of outstanding borrowings for up to one additional year. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, credit lines for
the Company and the related activity were as follows (in billions of dollars): </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's revolving credit facilities, which are for its sole use, require the maintenance of a minimum net worth of $18.2&nbsp;billion. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company's
net worth was $29.9&nbsp;billion. The Company expects to continue to meet this covenant. The foregoing revolving credit facilities do not include any other financial tests, any credit rating
triggers or any provisions that could require the posting of collateral. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the above, certain international subsidiaries of Kraft maintain uncommitted credit lines to meet the short-term working capital needs of the international
businesses. These credit lines, which amounted to approximately $600&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2004, are for the sole use of the Company's </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aggregate
maturities of long-term debt are as follows (in millions): </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Kraft
repurchases its Class&nbsp;A common stock in open market transactions. On December&nbsp;14, 2004, Kraft completed a multi-year $700&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A
common stock repurchase program, acquiring 21,718,847 Class&nbsp;A shares at an average price of $32.23 per share. During 2004, repurchases under the $700&nbsp;million program were 20,135,247
shares at a cost of $650&nbsp;million, or $32.28 per share. On December&nbsp;14, 2004, the Company commenced repurchasing shares under a new $1.5&nbsp;billion Class&nbsp;A common stock
repurchase program that was authorized by the Board of Directors on December&nbsp;2, 2004. Through December&nbsp;31, 2004, repurchases under the $1.5&nbsp;billion program were 1,408,413 shares
at a cost of $50&nbsp;million, or $35.49 per share. On December&nbsp;3, 2003, Kraft completed a $500&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A common stock repurchase program, acquiring 15,308,458
Class&nbsp;A shares at an average price of $32.66 per share. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, 1.18&nbsp;billion Class&nbsp;B common shares were issued and outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003. Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. holds 276.5&nbsp;million
Class&nbsp;A common shares and all of the Class&nbsp;B common shares at December&nbsp;31, 2004. There are no preferred shares issued and outstanding. Class&nbsp;A common shares are entitled to
one vote each, while Class&nbsp;B common shares are entitled to ten votes each. Therefore, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. holds 98.0% of the combined voting power of the Company's outstanding capital
stock at December&nbsp;31, 2004. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, 66,663,515 shares of common stock were reserved for stock options and other stock awards. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>64</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=65,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=474829,FOLIO='64',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DW1150A.;13',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dy1150_1_65"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock Plans:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the 2001 Kraft Performance Incentive Plan (the "2001 Plan"), the Company may grant stock options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock, reload
options and other awards based on the Company's Class&nbsp;A common stock, as well as performance-based annual and long-term incentive awards. A maximum of 75&nbsp;million shares of
the Company's Class&nbsp;A common stock may be issued under the 2001 Plan. In addition, the Company may grant up to 500,000 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock to members of the Board of Directors
who are not full-time employees of the Company or Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc., or their subsidiaries, under the Kraft Directors Plan (the "2001 Directors Plan"). Shares available to be
granted under the 2001 Plan and the 2001 Directors Plan at December&nbsp;31, 2004, were 46,707,241 and 458,633, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company applies the intrinsic value-based methodology in accounting for the various stock plans. Accordingly, no compensation expense has been recognized other than for restricted
stock awards. In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;123R, which requires companies to measure compensation cost for share-based payments at fair value. The Company will adopt this
new standard prospectively on July&nbsp;1, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock
option activity was as follows for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2003 and 2004: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior
to the IPO, certain employees of the Company participated in Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s stock compensation plans. Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. does not intend to issue additional
Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock compensation to the Company's employees, except for reloads of previously issued options. Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. accounts for its plans in accordance with the
intrinsic value-based method permitted by SFAS No.&nbsp;123, "Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation," which did not result in compensation cost for stock options. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, the Company's employees held options to purchase the following number of shares of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock: 39,241,651 shares at an average
exercise price of $37.25 per share at December&nbsp;31, 2003; and 46,615,162 shares at an average exercise price of $35.78 per share at December&nbsp;31, 2002. Of these amounts, the following were
exercisable at each
date: 39,025,325 at an average exercise price of $37.19 per share at December&nbsp;31, 2003; and 46,231,629 at an average exercise price of $35.69 per share at December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Had
compensation cost for stock option awards under the Kraft plans and Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. plans been determined by using the fair value at the grant date, the Company's net
earnings and basic and diluted EPS would have been $2,658&nbsp;million, $1.56 and $1.55, respectively, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004; $3,464&nbsp;million, $2.01 and $2.00,
respectively, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003; and $3,316&nbsp;million, $1.91 and $1.91, respectively, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. The foregoing impact of compensation
cost was determined using a modified Black-Scholes methodology and the following assumptions: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company may grant shares of restricted stock and rights to receive shares of stock to eligible employees, giving them in most instances all of the rights of stockholders, except that
they may not sell, assign, pledge or otherwise encumber such shares and rights. Such shares and rights are subject to forfeiture if certain employment conditions are not met. During 2004 and 2003, the
Company granted approximately 4.1&nbsp;million and 3.7&nbsp;million restricted Class&nbsp;A shares, respectively, to eligible U.S.-based employees, and during 2004 and 2003, also issued to
eligible non-U.S. employees rights to receive approximately 1.9&nbsp;million and 1.6&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A equivalent shares, respectively. The market value per restricted share
or right was $32.23 and $36.56 on the dates of the 2004 and 2003 grants, respectively. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, restrictions on these shares and rights, net of forfeitures, lapse as follows:
2005&#151;13,719 shares; 2006&#151;4,520,120 shares; 2007&#151;5,532,500 shares; 2009&#151;150,000 shares; and 2012&#151;100,000 shares. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fair value of the shares of restricted stock and rights to receive shares of stock at the date of grant is amortized to expense ratably over the restriction period. The Company
recorded compensation expense related to the restricted stock and rights of $106&nbsp;million and $57&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. The
unamortized portion, which is reported on the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>66</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=67,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=364962,FOLIO='66',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DY1150A.;16',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_dy1150_1_67"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>consolidated
balance sheets as a reduction of earnings reinvested in the business, was $190&nbsp;million and $129&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the 2003 computation, 18&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A common stock options were excluded from the calculation of weighted average shares for diluted EPS because their effects were
antidilutive. </FONT></P>

<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2>Total provision for income taxes</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>67</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=68,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=563507,FOLIO='67',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DY1150A.;16',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_dy1150_1_68"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
(loss) earnings from discontinued operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 included a deferred income tax benefit of $43&nbsp;million. The Company also anticipates
additional tax expense of approximately $270&nbsp;million in 2005, once the sale of its sugar confectionery business has been consummated. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2004, applicable United States federal income taxes and foreign withholding taxes have not been provided on approximately $3.8&nbsp;billion of accumulated
earnings of foreign subsidiaries that are expected to be permanently reinvested. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
October&nbsp;22, 2004, the American Jobs Creation Act ("the Jobs Act") was signed into law. The Jobs Act includes a deduction for 85% of certain foreign earnings that are
repatriated. The Company may elect to apply this provision to qualifying earnings repatriations in 2005 and is conducting analyses of its effects. The U.S. Treasury Department recently provided
additional clarifying language on key elements of the provision, which is under consideration as part of the Company's evaluation. The Company expects to complete its evaluation of the effects of the
repatriation provision within a reasonable period of time. The Company does not expect the repatriation provisions of the Jobs Act to have a significant impact on its consolidated results of
operations or its consolidated cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Jobs Act also provides tax relief to U.S. domestic manufacturers by providing a tax deduction up to 9% of the lesser of "qualified production activities income" or taxable income. In
December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position 109-1, "Application of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;109, "Accounting for Income Taxes,' to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production
Activities Provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004" ("FSP 109-1"). FSP 109-1 requires companies to account for this deduction as a "special deduction" rather than a
rate reduction, in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;109, and therefore, the Company will recognize these benefits, which are not expected to be significant, in the year earned. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
effective income tax rate on pre-tax earnings differed from the U.S. federal statutory rate for the following reasons for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003
and 2002: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>68</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=69,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=574484,FOLIO='68',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DY1150A.;16',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_dy1150_1_69"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;14.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment Reporting:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company manufactures and markets packaged food products, consisting principally of beverages, cheese, snacks, convenient meals and various packaged grocery
products. Kraft manages and reports operating results through two units, Kraft North America Commercial and Kraft International Commercial. Reportable segments for Kraft North America Commercial are
organized and managed principally by product category. Kraft International Commercial's operations are organized and managed by geographic location. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
January&nbsp;2004, the Company announced a new global organizational structure, which resulted in new segments. During the fourth quarter of 2004, following the sale of its
sugar confectionery business, as discussed in Note&nbsp;5. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Divestitures</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, the Company realigned its North American segments. Kraft North America
Commercial's new segments are U.S. Beverages; U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America Foodservice; U.S. Convenient Meals; U.S. Grocery; and U.S. Snacks&nbsp;&amp; Cereals. Kraft International
Commercial's segments are Europe, Middle East&nbsp;&amp; Africa; and Latin America&nbsp;&amp; Asia Pacific. The new segment structure in North America reflects a shift of certain divisions and brands
between segments to more closely align these businesses to consumer sectors, to provide more focus on the separate beverage and grocery businesses, and to benefit from synergies in grain based
products. Historical data have been restated to reflect the new segment structure. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's management uses operating companies income, which is defined as operating income before general corporate expenses and amortization of intangibles, to evaluate segment
performance and allocate resources. Management believes it is appropriate to disclose this measure to help investors analyze the business performance and trends of the various business segments.
Interest and other debt expense, net, and provision for income taxes are centrally managed and, accordingly, such items are not presented by segment since they are not included in the measure of
segment profitability reviewed by management. The Company's assets, which are principally in the United States and Europe, are managed geographically. The accounting policies of the segments are the
same as those described in Note&nbsp;2. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>69</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=70,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=421649,FOLIO='69',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]DY1150A.;16',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_ea1150_1_70"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment data were as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=3 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=8 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>For the Years Ended<BR>
December 31,</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=3 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2004</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2003</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2002</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=3 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=8 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>(in millions)<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
</TR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's largest customer, Wal-Mart Stores,&nbsp;Inc. and its affiliates, accounted for approximately 14%, 12% and 12% of consolidated net revenues for 2004, 2003 and
2002, respectively. These net revenues occurred primarily in the United States and were across all segments. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>70</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=71,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=800953,FOLIO='70',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]EA1150A.;32',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_ea1150_1_71"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues by consumer sector, which include the separation of Canada and North America Foodservice into sector components, were as follows for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2004, 2003 and 2002: </FONT></P>

<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
</TR>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>71</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=72,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=780804,FOLIO='71',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]EA1150A.;32',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_ea1150_1_72"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Items
affecting the comparability of the Company's continuing operating results were as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>As discussed in Note&nbsp;3. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset
Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, the Company recorded asset impairment, exit and implementation costs of $700&nbsp;million, $6&nbsp;million and
$142&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively. See Note&nbsp;3 for the breakdown of these pre-tax charges by segment.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Losses (Gains) on Sales of Businesses&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>During 2004, the Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and
trademarks associated with a candy business in Norway for aggregate pre-tax losses of $3&nbsp;million. During 2003, the Company sold a European rice business and a branded fresh cheese
business in Italy for aggregate pre-tax gains of $31&nbsp;million. During 2002, the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Company</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> sold its Latin American yeast and industrial
bakery ingredients business, resulting in a pre-tax gain of $69&nbsp;million, and several small food businesses, resulting in pre-tax gains of $11&nbsp;million. These
pre-tax losses (gains) were included in the operating companies income of the following segments: </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Benefit Plans:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2003, the FASB issued a revised SFAS No.&nbsp;132, "Employers' Disclosures about Pensions and Other Postretirement Benefits." In accordance
with the pronouncement, the Company adopted the revised disclosure requirements of this pronouncement for its U.S. plans in 2003 and for its non-U.S. plans in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company sponsors noncontributory defined benefit pension plans covering substantially all U.S. employees. Pension coverage for employees of the Company's non-U.S.
subsidiaries is provided, to the extent deemed appropriate, through separate plans, many of which are governed by local statutory requirements. In addition, the Company's U.S. and Canadian
subsidiaries provide health care and other benefits to substantially all retired employees. Health care benefits for retirees outside the United States and Canada are generally covered through local
government plans. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
plan assets and benefit obligations of the Company's U.S. and Canadian pension plans are measured at December&nbsp;31 of each year and all other non-U.S. pension plans
are measured at September&nbsp;30 of each year. The benefit obligations of the Company's postretirement plans are measured at December&nbsp;31 of each year. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>74</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
combined U.S. and non-U.S. pension plans resulted in a net prepaid pension asset of $2,404&nbsp;million and $1,985&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003,
respectively. These amounts were recognized in the Company's consolidated balance sheets at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, as prepaid pension assets of $3,569&nbsp;million and
$3,243&nbsp;million, respectively, for those plans in which plan assets exceeded their accumulated benefit obligations, and as other liabilities of $1,165&nbsp;million and $1,258&nbsp;million,
respectively, for plans in which the accumulated benefit obligations exceeded their plan assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
U.S. and non-U.S. pension plans, the change in the additional minimum liability in 2004 and 2003 was as follows: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>75</FONT></P>

<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=76,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=551173,FOLIO='75',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]EA1150A.;32',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_ea1150_1_76"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
accumulated benefit obligation for the U.S. pension plans was $5,327&nbsp;million and $4,898&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. The accumulated
benefit obligation for the non-U.S. pension plans was $3,251&nbsp;million and $2,708&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, certain of the Company's U.S. pension plans were underfunded, with projected benefit obligations, accumulated benefit obligations and the fair value
of plan assets of $260&nbsp;million, $188&nbsp;million and $11&nbsp;million, respectively, in 2004, and $261&nbsp;million, $208&nbsp;million and
$14&nbsp;million, respectively, in 2003. The majority of these relate to plans for salaried employees that cannot be funded under IRS regulations. For certain non-U.S. plans, which have
accumulated benefit obligations in excess of plan assets, the projected benefit obligation, accumulated benefit obligation and fair value of plan assets were $2,012&nbsp;million,
$1,877&nbsp;million and $950&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2004, and $1,648&nbsp;million, $1,532&nbsp;million and $588&nbsp;million, respectively, as of
December&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following weighted-average assumptions were used to determine the Company's benefit obligations under the plans at December&nbsp;31: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> Components of Net Periodic Benefit Cost  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net periodic pension cost (income) consisted of the following for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Retiring
employees elected lump-sum payments, resulting in settlement losses of $41&nbsp;million, $51&nbsp;million and $21&nbsp;million in 2004, 2003 and 2002,
respectively. In addition, during 2002, certain salaried employees in the United States left the Company under a voluntary early retirement program instituted in 2001. This resulted in special
termination benefits and curtailment and settlement losses of $109&nbsp;million in 2002. In 2004, a non-U.S. plant closure and early retirement benefits resulted in curtailment and
settlement losses of $7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>76</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's expected rate of return on plan assets is determined by the plan assets' historical long-term investment performance, current asset allocation and estimates of
future long-term returns by asset class. The Company has reduced this assumption to 8% in determining its U.S. plans pension expense for 2005. In 2005, the discount rate used to determine
the Company's net pension cost for its U.S. plans will be 5.75% and the rate of compensation increase for its U.S. plans will be 4.00%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Kraft
and certain of its subsidiaries sponsor employee savings plans, to which the Company contributes. These plans cover certain salaried, non-union and union employees. The
Company's contributions and costs are determined by the matching of employee contributions, as defined by the plans. Amounts charged to expense for defined contribution plans totaled
$92&nbsp;million, $84&nbsp;million and $64&nbsp;million in 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> Plan Assets  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The percentage of fair value of pension plan assets at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, was as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's investment strategy is based on an expectation that equity securities will outperform debt securities over the long term. Accordingly, the composition of the Company's U.S.
plan assets is broadly characterized as a 70%/30% allocation between equity and debt securities. The strategy utilizes indexed U.S. equity securities and actively managed investment grade debt
securities (which constitute 80% or more of debt securities) with lesser allocations to high yield and international debt securities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the plans outside the U.S., the investment strategy is subject to local regulations and the asset/liability profiles of the plans in each individual country. These specific
circumstances result in
a level of equity exposure that is typically less than the U.S. plans. In aggregate, the actual asset allocations of the non-U.S. plans are virtually identical to their respective asset
policy targets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company attempts to mitigate investment risk by rebalancing between equity and debt asset classes as the Company's contributions and monthly benefit payments are made. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company presently plans to make contributions, to the extent that they are tax deductible, in order to maintain plan assets in excess of the accumulated benefit obligation of its
funded U.S. and non-U.S. plans. Currently, the Company anticipates making contributions of approximately $250&nbsp;million in 2005 to its U.S. plans and approximately $90&nbsp;million
in 2005 to its non-U.S. plans, based on current tax law. However, these estimates are subject to change as a result of changes in tax law, as well as asset </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>77</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=78,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=968011,FOLIO='77',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]EA1150A.;32',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_ea1150_1_78"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>performance
significantly above or below the assumed long-term rate of return on pension assets, or significant changes in interest rates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2002, certain salaried employees in the United States left the Company under a voluntary early retirement program instituted in 2001. This resulted in curtailment losses of
$16&nbsp;million in 2002, which are included in other expense above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2003, the United States enacted into law the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 (the "Act"). The Act establishes a prescription drug
benefit under Medicare, known as "Medicare Part&nbsp;D," and a federal subsidy to sponsors of retiree health care benefit plans that provide a benefit that is at least actuarially equivalent to
Medicare Part&nbsp;D. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
May&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position No.&nbsp;106-2, "Accounting and Disclosure Requirements Related to the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and
Modernization Act of 2003" ("FSP 106-2"). FSP 106-2 requires companies to account for the effect of the subsidy on benefits attributable to past service as an actuarial
experience gain and as a reduction of the service cost component of net postretirement health care costs for amounts attributable to current service, if the benefit provided is at least actuarially
equivalent to Medicare Part&nbsp;D. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company adopted FSP 106-2 in the third quarter of 2004. The impact of adoption for 2004 was a reduction of pre-tax net postretirement health care costs and an
increase in net earnings of $24&nbsp;million, which is included above as a reduction of $3&nbsp;million in service cost, $10&nbsp;million in interest cost and $11&nbsp;million in amortization
of unrecognized net loss from experience differences. In addition, as of July&nbsp;1, 2004, the Company reduced its accumulated postretirement benefit obligation for the subsidy related to benefits
attributed to past service by $315&nbsp;million and decreased its unrecognized actuarial losses by the same amount. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>78</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=79,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=580769,FOLIO='78',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]EA1150A.;32',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_ea1150_1_79"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following weighted-average assumptions were used to determine the Company's net postretirement cost for the years ended December&nbsp;31: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<TH WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2003</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2002</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="32%"><FONT SIZE=2>Discount rate</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>6.25</FONT></TD>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2005, the discount rate used to determine the Company's net postretirement cost will be 5.75% and the health care cost trend rate will be 8.00% for its U.S. plans and 9.50% for its
Canadian plans. </FONT></P>

current portion of the Company's accrued postretirement health care costs of $217&nbsp;million and $199&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively, are

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Postemployment Benefit Plans  </I></FONT></P>

is charged to expense over the working life of the covered employees. Net postemployment costs consisted of the following for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
previously discussed in Note&nbsp;3. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, the Company announced several workforce
reduction programs during 2004 as part of the overall restructuring program. The cost of these programs, $167&nbsp;million, is included in other expense above. During 2002, certain salaried
employees in the United States left the Company under voluntary early retirement and integration programs. These programs resulted in incremental postemployment costs of $23&nbsp;million, which are
included in other expense above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
accumulated benefit obligation was determined using an assumed ultimate annual turnover rate of 0.3% in 2004 and 2003, assumed compensation cost increases of 4.0% in 2004 and 2003,
and assumed benefits as defined in the respective plans. Postemployment costs arising from actions that offer employees benefits in excess of those specified in the respective plans are charged to
expense when incurred. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;17.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financial Instruments:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Derivative financial instruments  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company operates globally, with manufacturing and sales facilities in various locations around the world, and utilizes certain financial instruments to manage
its foreign currency and commodity exposures. Derivative financial instruments are used by the Company, principally to reduce exposures to market risks resulting from fluctuations in foreign exchange
rates and commodity prices by creating offsetting exposures. The Company is not a party to leveraged derivatives and, by policy, does not use financial instruments for speculative purposes. Financial
instruments qualifying for hedge accounting must maintain a specified level of effectiveness between the hedging instrument and the item being hedged, both at inception and throughout the hedged
period. The Company formally documents the nature of and relationships between the hedging instruments and hedged items, as well as its risk-management objectives, strategies for
undertaking the various hedge transactions and method of assessing hedge effectiveness. Additionally, for hedges of forecasted transactions, the significant characteristics and expected terms of the
forecasted transaction must be specifically identified, and it must be probable that each forecasted transaction will occur. If it were deemed probable that the forecasted transaction will not occur,
the gain or loss would be recognized in earnings currently. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company uses forward foreign exchange contracts and foreign currency options to mitigate its exposure to changes in exchange rates from third-party and intercompany actual and
forecasted transactions. Substantially all of the Company's derivative financial instruments are effective as hedges. The primary currencies to which the Company is exposed, based on the size and
location of its </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>81</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=82,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=997653,FOLIO='81',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]EC1150A.;16',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_ec1150_1_82"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>businesses,
include the euro, Swiss franc, British pound and Canadian dollar. At December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the Company had foreign exchange option and forward contracts with aggregate
notional amounts of $2.9&nbsp;billion and $2.5&nbsp;billion, respectively. The effective portion of unrealized gains and losses associated with forward and option contracts is deferred as a
component of accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) until the underlying hedged transactions are reported on the Company's consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company is exposed to price risk related to forecasted purchases of certain commodities used as raw materials by its businesses. Accordingly, the Company uses commodity forward
contracts as cash flow hedges, primarily for coffee, cocoa, milk and cheese. Commodity futures and options are also used to hedge the price of certain commodities, including milk, coffee, cocoa,
wheat, corn, sugar and soybean oil. In general, commodity forward contracts qualify for the normal purchase exception under SFAS No.&nbsp;133 and are, therefore, not subject to the provisions of
SFAS No.&nbsp;133. At December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the Company had net long commodity positions of $443&nbsp;million and $255&nbsp;million, respectively. Unrealized gains or losses on net
commodity positions were immaterial at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003. The effective portion of unrealized gains and losses on commodity futures and option contracts is deferred as a component of
accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) and is recognized as a component of cost of sales in the Company's consolidated statement of earnings when the related inventory is sold. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ineffectiveness
related to cash flow hedges was not material for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company was hedging forecasted
transactions for periods not exceeding fifteen months and expects substantially all amounts reported in accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) to be reclassified to the consolidated
statement of earnings within the next twelve months. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Derivative
gains or losses reported in accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) are a result of qualifying hedging activity. Transfers of gains or losses from accumulated other
comprehensive earnings (losses) to earnings are offset by corresponding gains or losses on the underlying hedged item. Hedging activity affected accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses), net
of income taxes, during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, as follows (in millions): </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Credit exposure and credit risk  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is exposed to credit loss in the event of nonperformance by counterparties. However, the Company does not anticipate nonperformance, and such exposure
was not material at December&nbsp;31, 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Fair value  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The aggregate fair value, based on market quotes, of the Company's third-party debt at December&nbsp;31, 2004, was $12,835&nbsp;million as compared with its
carrying value of $12,291&nbsp;million. The aggregate fair value of the Company's third-party debt at December&nbsp;31, 2003, was $13,426&nbsp;million as compared with its carrying value of
$12,919&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
Notes 4, 8 and 9 for additional disclosures of fair value for short-term borrowings and long-term debt. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>82</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=83,EFW="2152234",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=629064,FOLIO='82',FILE='DISK009:[05CHI0.05CHI1150]EC1150A.;16',USER='LCOUTU',CD=';9-MAR-2005;21:22' -->
<A NAME="page_ec1150_1_83"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;18.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Contingencies:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Kraft and its subsidiaries are parties to a variety of legal proceedings arising out of the normal course of business, including a few cases in which substantial
amounts of damages are sought. While the results of litigation cannot be predicted with certainty, management believes that the final outcome of these proceedings will not have a material adverse
effect on the Company's consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Third-Party Guarantees  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company's third-party guarantees, which are primarily derived from acquisition and divestiture activities, approximated
$25&nbsp;million. Substantially all of these guarantees
expire through 2013, with $1&nbsp;million expiring during 2005. The Company is required to perform under these guarantees in the event that a third party fails to make contractual payments or
achieve performance measures. The Company has a liability of $20&nbsp;million on its consolidated balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2004, relating to these guarantees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ej1150_item_9._changes_in_and_disagre__ite03557"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ej1150_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item&nbsp;9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Changes in and Disagreements with Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure.</I></B></FONT></P>

</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ej1150_item_9a._controls_and_procedures."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ej1150_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 9A.&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Controls and Procedures.</I></B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company carried out an evaluation, with the participation of the Company's management, including the Company's Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, of the
effectiveness of the Company's disclosure controls and procedures (pursuant to Rule&nbsp;13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended) as of the end of the period
covered by this report. Based upon that evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that the Company's disclosure controls and procedures are effective in timely
alerting them to material information relating to the Company (including its consolidated subsidiaries) required to be included in the Company's reports filed or submitted under the Securities
Exchange Act of 1934, as amended. Our management evaluated, with the participation of the Company's Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, any change in the Company's internal control
over financial reporting and determined that there has been no change in the Company's internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 that has materially
affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company's internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
also "Report of Management on Internal Control over Financial Reporting" in Item&nbsp;8. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ej1150_item_9b._other_information."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ej1150_3"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;None. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All
of the above-named officers have been employed by the Company in various capacities during the past five years, except for Mr.&nbsp;Firestone, Ms.&nbsp;Hefner and
Mr.&nbsp;Berlind. Prior to joining the Company in 2003, Mr.&nbsp;Firestone was Senior Vice President and General Counsel for Philip Morris International&nbsp;Inc. From 1998 until 2001, he was
Chief Counsel for Philip Morris Europe. Prior to joining the Company in 2004, Ms.&nbsp;Hefner held various positions with the Sara Lee Corporation since 1989. Most recently, she served as Chief
Executive Officer of Sara Lee Underwear, Socks&nbsp;&amp; Latin America Group. Prior to joining the Company in 2004, Mr.&nbsp;Berlind held various positions with Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. since 1996.
Most recently, he served as Vice President and Associate General Counsel for Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., a subsidiary of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has adopted a code of ethics as defined in Item 406 of Regulation&nbsp;S-K, which code applies to all of its employees, including its principal executive
officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting officer or controller, and persons performing similar functions. This code of ethics, which is entitled The Kraft Foods Code of Conduct for
Compliance and Integrity, is available free of charge on the Company's website at www.kraft.com and will be provided free of charge to any stockholder requesting a copy by writing to: Corporate
Secretary, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., Three Lakes Drive, Northfield, IL 60093. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, the Company has adopted corporate governance guidelines and charters for its Audit Committee, Compensation Committee and Nominating and Governance Committee, as well as a
code of business conduct and ethics that applies to the members of its Board of Directors. All of these materials are available on the Company's website at www.kraft.com and will be provided free of
charge to any stockholder requesting a copy by writing to: Corporate Secretary, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., Three Lakes Drive, Northfield, IL 60093. Certain of these materials may also be found in the
proxy statement relating to the Company's 2005 Annual Meeting of Stockholders. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
information on the Company's website is not, and shall not be deemed to be, a part of this Report or incorporated into any other filings the Company makes with the SEC. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May&nbsp;25, 2004, the Company filed its Annual CEO Certification as required by Section&nbsp;303A.12 of the New York Stock Exchange Listed Company Manual. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
also Item 11 for certain information that is incorporated by reference into this Item 10. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="el1150_item_11._executive_compensation."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_el1150_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 11. </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Executive Compensation.    <BR>    </I></B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Except for the information relating to the executive officers of, and certain documents adopted by, the Company set forth in Item 10 of this Report and the
information regarding equity compensation plans set forth in Item 12 below, the information called for by Items 10-14 is hereby incorporated by reference to the Company's definitive proxy
statement for use in connection with its annual meeting of shareholders to be held on April&nbsp;26, 2005, filed with the SEC on March&nbsp;4, 2005, and, except as indicated therein, is made a
part hereof. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>87</FONT></P>

other than those listed above have been omitted either because such schedules are not required or are not applicable. </FONT></P>

or arrangements):</I></FONT></DD></DL>

<A NAME="toc_ji1150_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM<BR>  ON FINANCIAL STATEMENT SCHEDULE    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>To
the Board of Directors and Shareholders of<BR>
Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc.: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
audits of the consolidated financial statements, of management's assessment of the Company's internal control over financial reporting and of the effectiveness of the Company's
internal control over financial reporting referred to in our report dated February&nbsp;2, 2005 appearing in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K also included an audit of the
financial statement schedule listed in Item 15(a) of this Form&nbsp;10-K. In our opinion, this financial statement schedule presents fairly, in all material respects, the information set
forth therein when read in conjunction with the related consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>/s/&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2>PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Chicago,
Illinois<BR>
February&nbsp;2, 2005 </FONT></P>

related to divestitures, acquisitions and currency translation.

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Exhibit 23  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="kb1433_consent_of_independent___kb102325"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_kb1433_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>CONSENT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We hereby consent to the incorporation by reference in the Registration Statements on Form&nbsp;S-8 (File Nos. 333-71266 and
333-84616) of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. (the "Company") and in the Company's Registration Statements on Form&nbsp;S-3 (File Nos. 333-67770, 333-86478,
333-101829 and 333-113620), of our reports dated February&nbsp;2, 2005 relating to the financial statements, management's assessment of the effectiveness of internal control
over financial reporting and the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting and financial statement schedule, which appear in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>/s/
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP<BR>
Chicago, Illinois<BR>
March&nbsp;11, 2005 </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-24
<SEQUENCE>4
<FILENAME>a2152234zex-24.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EX-24
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" LINK=BLUE  VLINK=PURPLE>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=3 ><A HREF="#05CHI1150_4">QuickLinks</A></FONT>
<font size=3> -- Click here to rapidly navigate through this document</font>
<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Exhibit 24  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="kc1433_power_of_attorney"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_kc1433_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>POWER OF ATTORNEY    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KNOW ALL MEN BY THESE PRESENT THAT the undersigned, a Director of Kraft Foods Inc., a Virginia corporation (the "Company"), does hereby constitute and appoint
Louis&nbsp;C. Camilleri, Marc&nbsp;S. Firestone and James&nbsp;P. Dollive, or any one or more of them, his true and lawful attorney, for him and in his name, place and stead, to execute, by
manual or facsimile signature, electronic transmission or otherwise, the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K of the Company for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and any amendments or supplements
to said Annual Report and to cause the same to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, together with any exhibits, financial statements and schedules included or to be incorporated by
reference therein, hereby granting to said attorneys full power and authority to do and perform all and every act and thing whatsoever requisite or desirable to be done in and about the premises as
fully to all intents and purposes as the undersigned might or could do in person, hereby ratifying and confirming all acts and things which said attorneys may do or cause to be done by virtue of these
present. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IN
WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned has hereunto set his hand and seal this 28th day of February, 2005. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>POWER OF ATTORNEY  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KNOW
ALL MEN BY THESE PRESENT THAT the undersigned, a Director of Kraft Foods Inc., a Virginia corporation (the "Company"), does hereby constitute and appoint Louis&nbsp;C. Camilleri,
Marc&nbsp;S. Firestone and James&nbsp;P. Dollive, or any one or more of them, his true and lawful attorney, for him and in his name, place and stead, to execute, by manual or facsimile signature,
electronic transmission or otherwise, the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K of the Company for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and any amendments or supplements to said Annual Report and to
cause the same to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, together with any exhibits, financial statements and schedules included or to be incorporated by reference therein, hereby
granting to said attorneys full power and authority to do and perform all and every act and thing whatsoever requisite or desirable to be done in and about the premises as fully to all intents and
purposes as the undersigned might or could do in person, hereby ratifying and confirming all acts and things which said attorneys may do or cause to be done by virtue of these present. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IN
WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned has hereunto set his hand and seal this 28th day of February, 2005. </FONT></P>

<FONT SIZE=3 ><A HREF="#05CHI1150_5">QuickLinks</A></FONT>
<font size=3> -- Click here to rapidly navigate through this document</font>
<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Exhibit 31.1  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ke1433_certifications"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ke1433_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Certifications    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>I,
Roger K. Deromedi, certify that: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>1.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>I
have reviewed this annual report on Form 10-K of Kraft Foods Inc.;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>2.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the
circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>3.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>4.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act
Rules&nbsp;13a-15(e)&nbsp;and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f)&nbsp;and 15d-15(f)) for the registrant and have:
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Designed
such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating
to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities,particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Designed
such internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance
regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(c)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Evaluated
the effectiveness of the registrant's disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and
procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(d)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Disclosed
in this report any change in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrant's most recent fiscal quarter (the registrant's
fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrant's internal control over financial reporting; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD></DL>
</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>5.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant's auditors and the
audit committee of the registrant's board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>All
significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the
registrant's ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Any
fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></DD></DL>
</DD></DL>
<BR>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Date: March&nbsp;11, 2005</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>/s/&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>ROGER K. DEROMEDI</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><HR NOSHADE><FONT SIZE=2> Roger K. Deromedi<BR>
Chief Executive Officer</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-31.2
<SEQUENCE>6
<FILENAME>a2152234zex-31_2.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EX-31.2
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" LINK=BLUE  VLINK=PURPLE>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=3 ><A HREF="#05CHI1150_6">QuickLinks</A></FONT>
<font size=3> -- Click here to rapidly navigate through this document</font>
<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Exhibit 31.2  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="kg1433_certifications"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_kg1433_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Certifications    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>I,
James P. Dollive, certify that: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>1.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>I
have reviewed this annual report on Form 10-K of Kraft Foods Inc.;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>2.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the
circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>3.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>4.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act
Rules&nbsp;13a-15(e)&nbsp;and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f)&nbsp;and 15d-15(f)) for the registrant and have:
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Designed
such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating
to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Designed
such internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance
regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(c)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Evaluated
the effectiveness of the registrant's disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and
procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(d)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Disclosed
in this report any change in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrant's most recent fiscal quarter (the registrant's
fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrant's internal control over financial reporting; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD></DL>
</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>5.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant's auditors and the
audit committee of the registrant's board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>All
significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the
registrant's ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Any
fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></DD></DL>
</DD></DL>
<BR>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

</TR>

<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>/s/&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>JAMES P. DOLLIVE</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><HR NOSHADE><FONT SIZE=2> James P. Dollive<BR>
Executive Vice President and<BR>
Chief Financial Officer</FONT></TD>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-32.1
<SEQUENCE>7
<FILENAME>a2152234zex-32_1.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EX-32.1
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" LINK=BLUE  VLINK=PURPLE>
<BR>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Exhibit 32.1  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>CERTIFICATION PURSUANT TO<BR>
18 U.S.C. SECTION 1350,<BR>
AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO<BR>
SECTION 906 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the Annual Report of Kraft Foods Inc. (the "Company") on Form&nbsp;10-K for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 as filed with the
Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the "Report"), I, Roger&nbsp;K. Deromedi, Chief Executive Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. &sect; 1350, as adopted
pursuant to &sect; 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
Report fully complies with the requirements of section 13(a)&nbsp;or 15(d)&nbsp;of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>/s/&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>ROGER K. DEROMEDI</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><HR NOSHADE><FONT SIZE=2> Roger K. Deromedi<BR>
Chief Executive Officer<BR>
March&nbsp;11, 2005</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>A signed original of this written statement required by Section&nbsp;906, or other document authenticating, acknowledging, or otherwise adopting the signature that appears in
typed form within the electronic version of this written statement required by Section 906, has been provided to Kraft Foods Inc. and will be retained by Kraft Foods Inc. and furnished to the
Securities and Exchange Commission or its staff upon request.  </I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" LINK=BLUE  VLINK=PURPLE>
<BR>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Exhibit 32.2  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>CERTIFICATION PURSUANT TO<BR>
18 U.S.C. SECTION 1350,<BR>
AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO<BR>
SECTION 906 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the Annual Report of Kraft Foods Inc. (the "Company") on Form&nbsp;10-K for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 as filed with the
Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the "Report"), I, James&nbsp;P. Dollive, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C.
&sect; 1350, as adopted pursuant to &sect; 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
Report fully complies with the requirements of section 13(a)&nbsp;or 15(d)&nbsp;of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>

Chief Financial Officer<BR>
March&nbsp;11, 2005</FONT></TD>

</TR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>A signed original of this written statement required by Section&nbsp;906, or other document authenticating, acknowledging, or otherwise adopting the signature that appears in
typed form within the electronic version of this written statement required by Section 906, has been provided to Kraft Foods Inc. and will be retained by Kraft Foods Inc. and furnished to the
Securities and Exchange Commission or its staff upon request.  </I></FONT></P>
